# Draft:Nan Kingdom

Nan Kingdom was a petty Tai  kingdom located in the Nan River Basin in modern Northern Thailand. Sometimes it was referred to Mueang Kao (), Kao country (), Principality of Kao (), Kaodesha (), or Kao Nan ().
History
Establishment and the annexation by Phayao
The Nan Kingdom was formally established in 1269 by  with the initial center at Mueang Yang () or Mueang Lang (; ) in the present day Ban Seaow (), , Nan province. The Rājavaṁśaprakaraṇa () in the Nan Chronicle complied by  says that the Kao dynasty of Nan was the decesdent of the 7th century monarch named Phaya Lao Ko (), a prince under the first monarch of Ngoenyang, Lao Chakkaraj. However, this claim was inconsistent with the context mentioned in the following chapter of the chronicle, and for the period of , there was no mention of such a dynasty. Some local legend says that Phaya Pukha had two sons, Khun Nun () and . The elder prince, Khun Nun, was sent to found Luang Prabang and ruled Lao people, while the younger Khun Fong was sent to ruled Mueang Pua or Varanagara () of the , a subgroup of the Gelao in 1282. Mueang Pua was the chief center after the death of Phaya Pukha, replacing Mueang Yang.
Following the death of  in 1303, his son, , succeeded the throne. However, Gao Guean was requested by his grandfather, Phaya Pukha, to back to rule Mueang Yang, which caused Gao Guean to pass the throne at Mueang Pua to his consort, . During the weak rule of Kham Pin, Mueang Pua faced the invasion by its northern Tai neighbor Phayao Kingdom led by , and finally fell under Phayao. Ngam Mueang assigned his queen consort, , and his son, Am Pom ) as the rulers, while the former Kham Pin fled to Ban Huai Raeng (), where she gave birth to the son, Khun Sai (), who later served as a local governer under  at Mueang Prad (). However, when Khun Sai gained enough military strength, he rebelled against the authority of  and made Mueang Pua an independent polity in 1323. He also married 's consort, , and enthroned as a new monarch of Mueang Pua under the regnal title . With , he had two sons, Chao Sai () and Chao Kan Mueang (), both later became kings of Muang Pua from 1349 to 1361.
Expansion and interstate conflicts
During the reign of  from 1323 to 1349, the kingdom became much more stable in terms of both political and economic. Phaya Pa Kong allied with King  of the Lan Na Kingdom in the raid campaign of the Phayao Kingdom during the reign of King Kham Lue (); however, both began to have problems and conflicts due to being taken advantage of in the ownership of property stolen from Phayao.
In 1359, Phaya Kan Mueang or Kran Mueang, moved the capital southward to Mueang Phu Phiang Chae Haeng as it was more suitable for agriculture and had easier access to trade with southern cities than the old capital. During this period, the Nan Kingdom had a good relationship, through the dynastic intermarriages, with the southern Tai kingdom of Sukhothai, and was considered a polity under Sukhothai since the reign of Maha Thammaracha I (r.1347–1368). However, the close tie between these two polities created dissatisfaction for the Siamese Ayutthaya Kingdom, who tried to expand influence into Sukhothai, which led to Phaya Kan Mueang being poisoned to death by an Ayutthaya spy. In response, , who succeeded his father, directly engaged in wars against Ayutthaya led by Borommarachathirat I by allying with Maha Thammaracha II of Sukhothai, but failed, and a lot of Nan soldiers were captured as hostages and were brought to Ayutthaya.
Due to the rapid growth of the seat at Mueang Phu Phiang Chae Haeng, causing the city to lack of water supply,  then relocated the capital to Wieng Tai () or the present-day Mueang Nan. He was succeeded by his son, Thao Kham Tan (), who was also poisoned to death by an Ayutthaya spy.

Rulers
The Kingdom of Nan possesses a historical development as long and continuous as that of the Sukhothai and Lan Na Kingdoms. It was governed by a succession of monarchs and ruling princes belonging to a hereditary royal lineage, altogether numbering more than 70 rulers throughout its history. The historical evolution and background of Nan can be divided into four distinct periods, as follows:
* 1st Period: The city-state of Nan in close association with the Sukhothai Kingdom.
* 2nd Period: Nan under the suzerainty of the Lan Na Kingdom.
* 3rd Period: Nan under the domination of the Burmese Kingdom.
* 4th Period: Nan under the rule of the Thonburi Kingdom and subsequently the Rattanakosin Kingdom.
